Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Lara B. Anderson at Virginia Tech.

Fundamental particle physics is at a critical moment in its development. New studies at the Large Hadron Collider, the Planck satellite and other experiments will give new information on possible physics beyond the Standard Model. This project is motivated by this goal. It is focused on string theory, which hopes to unify gravity with the other fundamental forces. String theory is only manifest at very high energy scales. To connect with experiment, the project concentrates on the development of "string phenomenology" - the aspect of string theory that attempts to bridge the gap between the high-energy, extra-dimensional formalism of string theory, and the low-energy, four-dimensional world of particles and forces. Despite the importance of string theory as the only known consistent quantum theory of gravity and its enormous power and flexibility for so-called "top down" model building in high energy physics, it is only recently that explicit low-energy limits of string theory have started to be developed to a level that makes serious interdisciplinary contact between string and particle phenomenology possible. Within string theory, the roles of physics and mathematics are intrinsically intertwined, and progress in string phenomenology requires cutting edge tools in modern mathematics. This project involves three of the primary approaches to particle phenomenology in string theory and interlinked approaches to string theory, algebraic geometry and high-speed mathematical computing. Now is the time to attempt to answer the question: can string theory give a description of the real world? And at last, with interdisciplinary mathematical and physical approaches and expanding computational power, string phenomenology is capable of doing just that. By exploring these new geometries, it may be possible to find a view of string theory that looks profoundly similar to the world we observe.

In heterotic string theory, the PI will generate a database of hundreds of billions of heterotic models (composed of Calabi-Yau 3-folds and vector bundles defined over them) and the analytic and algorithmic tools necessary to completely analyze the geometries and compute their local and topological data. The PI will also use new approaches in computational algebraic geometry to address long-standing phenomenological challenges in heterotic theory such as moduli stabilization and the determination of the full 4-dimensional, N=1 lagrangian (including the Kahler potential and normalized Yukawa couplings). Using the same mathematical toolkit outlined above, she will also study model building within global F-theory constructions. Despite being one of the most promising stringy approaches to particle phenomenology, F-theory is not fully understood. It is the goal to contribute to a rigorous framework for F-theory model building by systematically studying the geometry of Calabi-Yau 4-folds and the 2-dimensional cycles (or holes) within them that 7-branes wrap. In addition, the PI will explore new avenues of model building by introducing non-Abelian gauge field vacuum expectation values (vector bundles) over 7-brane stacks. Finally, the PI will study compact singular manifolds with G2 holonomy as backgrounds for M-theory and will also investigate the special (singular) points in 7-dimensional spaces of G2 holonomy (and their intersections), and derive the explicit 4-dimensional effective field theory of a compactification of M-theory in the neighborhood of these singularities. The PI hopes for the first time to produce globally defined G2 compactifications of M-theory. A combination of these three approaches should yield a new view of string phenomenology in string theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research on interconnected questions in string phenomenology and geometry. In order to obtain effective theories relevant for modeling real world phenomena, it is necessary to reduce the high energy, extra dimensional formalism of string theory to a 4-dimensional theory by "compactifying". That is, some of the extra dimensions intrinsic to string theory are are chosen to take the form of a compact "internal" space, leaving behind a 4-dimensional theory perhaps useful for a wide range of physics applications, including particle physics to cosmology. The form of this compact internal space -- the string "geometry" -- determines crucial properties of the effective theory (e.g. particle couplings and masses). The relationship between the geometry of compact backgrounds and the physics they determine can lead to new and important insights in both pure geometry and physics.


In this project, a wide range of string geometries were investigated and new results were obtained on several important topics, including:

-Calabi-Yau (CY) geometries are one of the most important compact backgrounds for string compactifications. Despite their long history in the field, only a few (algebraic) constructions exist for explicitly constructing datasets of such manifolds. Here a novel construction of Calabi-Yau manifolds was developed called "generalized complete intersection CYs (gCICYs). An initial dataset of 6000 manifolds included examples of topologies distinct from any that has appeared in the literature to date.


-Within heterotic string theory we developed a novel approach to a heterotic "duality" -- relating distinct string compactifications (i.e. distinct geometries) which could lead to the same effective 4-dimensional physics. New evidence for this (0,2) target space duality was provided which broadened its potential applications. In addition, a powerful no-go theorem was proven for smooth heterotic CY models with hypercharge flux breaking, where the visible E8 gauge group is directly broken to the symmetry group of the Standard Model of particle physics. The required alternative E8 embeddings of hypercharge were classified and a general no-go theorem proved which asserts that no suitable geometry and vector bundle leading to a realistic standard model particle spectrum can be found.


-Within F-theory, novel solutions of flux vacua were discovered in so-called "T-brane" solutions. These solutions broaden our understanding of the geometry of singular CY manifolds and develop novel links between CY geometry and that of Wild Hitchin systems.


-This work undertook several systematic studies of the geometry of genus-one/elliptically fibered CY manifolds which form an essential part of F-theory compactifications. New tools were developed to systematically search for fibration structures in CY manifolds. This has led to remarkable observations that the vast majority of all known CY manifolds are genus-one fibered. In fact, many CY geometries can be described as fibrations in dozens of ways, leading to new string dualities.


-The duality of heterotic string and F-theory compactifications was investigated. Here past results relating moduli of the two theories were generalized. This included exploring certain types of novel transitions in 4- and 6-dimensional quantum field theories, resulting from F-theory compactification. These transitions involve a change in the matter contentof the theory (via an intermediate superconformal field theory) while maintaining a fixed gauge group.


These results were shared in ten peer-reviewed publications, as well as numerous presentations at conferences and workshops. In addition, this project partially supported two graduate students, as well as one postdoctoral researcher.


The broader impacts of this funding included graduate student training, service to the wider research community, and efforts to support under-represented minorities in science. The PI has been actively involved in organizing research meetings/conferences that increase the dialog between mathematicians and physicists.  In total, 6 major conferences/workshops were organized in the past three years, including an APS Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics in 2017 and String Phenomenology 2017. One workshop was organized in cooperation with the Association of Women in Mathematics and highlighted the work of young female researchers in mathematics and physics). The PI was also actively involved in supporting female/minority students in science at Virginia Tech and in regional science outreach initiatives. These efforts have included serving as a mentor to the “Ladies of Robeson” (the society of female physics students at VT), the VT Honors society, and an ongoing commitment to giving science talks in regional K-12 schools.
